headline: Budget depends on comfort level, destination, and trip length
summary: Safari costs range from $150 per person per day for budget options to $3,000+ for ultra-luxury. For a mid-range Tanzania safari, expect $400-700 per person per day including accommodation, meals, game drives, and park fees. A 7-day trip typically costs $3,500-5,000 per person before international flights. Botswana costs 2-3x more than East Africa for equivalent quality.

assumptions.text: Budget safaris run $150-300/day, mid-range $400-700/day, luxury $800-1,500/day, ultra-luxury $1,500-3,000+/day.
Botswana prices are 2-3x higher than East Africa due to high-cost, low-volume tourism policy.
Internal flights add $200-500 per person per segment in Tanzania.
Adding gorilla trekking requires budgeting $1,500+ per person for Rwanda permits or $700+ for Uganda.

gains: Higher budget: Better guides, locations, and comfort between drives
Mid-range: Good balance of quality and value
Budget: More days in the bush for the same total spend
Luxury: Exceptional service and often better concession access
losses: Higher budget: Significant cost that may limit trip length
Mid-range: Neither the cheapest nor the best
Budget: Compromises on accommodation, guides, and vehicle privacy
Luxury: May feel the wildlife justifies a simpler approach

change_conditions: If traveling solo, add 30-50% for single supplements at most camps.
If Botswana is included, budget needs to increase 2-3x compared to East Africa.
If internal flights are needed in Tanzania, add $500-1,000 per person total.
If gorillas are included, add $2,000+ per person for permits and logistics.
